COMPANIES

ABC said it would impose a new system for measuring the TV audiences that advertisers pay to reach. Ad executives, caught by surprise, said they would fight ABC's plans to base audience guarantees in part on a three-year trend of viewing levels, instead of only Nielsen reports. [Page A1.]

Nynex was indicted by a Federal grand jury, charged with criminal contempt of the 1982 consent decree that broke up A.T.&T. because it sells computer data processing services over telephone lines to MCI. [D1.]

Chrysler swiftly realigned top management a day after the abrupt resignation of its vice chairman, Gerald Greenwald, but did so in a way that appears to add to uncertainty about who will succeed Lee A. Iacocca. [D1.]

Carolco Pictures sold a 10 percent stake to a Japanese electronics company for $60 million. The move is the latest illustration of the international business ties being forged by American entertainment companies. [D1.]
Paul Stuart will open more than 15 stores in Japan and elsewhere in Asia in a few years. [D3.]
Westinghouse Electric's board voted to exempt the company from coverage under Pennsylvania's new anti-takeover law. [D3.]
THE ECONOMY
The Government should ''actively intervene'' to keep U.S. ownership of industries critical to national security, a Defense Department task force has recommended. [D2.]
Orders to U.S. factories slumped 2.3 percent in April, the Commerce Department said. The decline pushed orders down 2 percent for the year so far. [D2.]
Prices farmers get for raw products rose 2 percent in May, raising the overall commodity index 3.4 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said. [D2.]
INTERNATIONAL

A meeting of finance ministers ended with officials saying they had made some progress in global trade talks despite sharp differences between the United States and the European Community over agricultural trade. [D1.]
MARKETS
The S.E.C. approved a pilot plan under which 100 stocks now traded in the over-the-counter market could also be traded on four exchanges, including the American Stock Exchange. [D1.]

Stock prices slid narrowly in late trading as investors turned skittish in advance of the release of economic data today that could show strong inflationary pressures. The Dow closed at 2,876.66, off 1.90. [D4.]
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading. [D11.]
The dollar advanced against most major currencies except the Canadian dollar in advance of today's release of employment figures for May. [D12.]
Prices of unleaded gasoline plunged the daily limit on the New York Mercantile Exchange because of an unexpected increase in the nation's stocks of crude oil and gasoline. [D12.]
TODAY'S COLUMNS
The Stanford Law and Policy Review estiimates that the full cost of the savings and loan crisis will come to $456.3 billion over the 10-year period from 1989-99. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Environmental companies in Europe are looking attractive, as a result of dirty water, dirty air, acid rain, hazardous waste, sewage and little room for landfills. Market Place. [D4.]

TV executives are questioning the analysis used by Whittle Communications to support its claim that its broadcasts into doctors' waiting rooms will reach consumers whom network television does not attract. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D15.]
